dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, you know, it's been a pretty wild week. All the protests happening across the country, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host_B, you know, it's been a pretty wild week. All the protests happening across the country, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely, [overlaps] devastating stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely, devastating stuff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, but then, like, the S&P 500, um, it just had its best 50-day streak *ever* on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then, like, the S and P five hundred, um, it just had its best fifty-day streak ever on Wednesday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? Are you kidding me? While all that was going on? That's, like, totally wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Are you kidding me? While all that was going on? That's, like, totally wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It seems, uh, completely unprecedented, this kind of dance between the market and, you know, the streets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It seems, uh, completely unprecedented, this kind of dance between the market and, you know, the streets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it *feels* unprecedented. Like, how can these two things be so divorced?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it feels unprecedented. Like, how can these two things be so divorced?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, actually, that's where it gets interesting. We looked back, and, um, it's not quite as new as it seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, actually, that's where it gets interesting. We looked back, and, um, it's not quite as new as it seems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Like, what kind of stuff are we talking about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Like, what kind of stuff are we talking about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Think about it: 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P actually went up almost 20%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Think about it: nineteen sixty three, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S and P actually went up almost twenty percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. [overlaps] I would've thought the opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. I would've thought the opposite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] And then, like, 1967, Vietnam protests, soaring 20%. Or 1968, Dr. King assassinated, still up 8%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, like, nineteen sixty seven, Vietnam protests, soaring twenty percent. Or nineteen sixty eight, Doctor King assassinated, still up eight percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1967, the year of the Vietnam protests, the S&P soared more than 20%. In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the market just… doesn't care? Is that what we're saying?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the market just... doesn't care? Is that what we're saying?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Jim Cramer, he put it pretty bluntly. He said, um, "the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Jim Cramer, he put it pretty bluntly. He said, um, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. That's a pretty cynical take, but, like, I guess it makes sense in a way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. That's a pretty cynical take, but, like, I guess it makes sense in a way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. And what experts are saying now is that investors are kind of ignoring the "three Ps"—pandemic, protests, politics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. And what experts are saying now is that investors are kind of ignoring the three Ps-pandemic, protests, politics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay. [overlaps] What *are* they focused on then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay. What are they focused on then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] They're focused on, um, what they see as a quicker and better-than-expected economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're focused on, um, what they see as a quicker and better-than-expected economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But is that really realistic? I mean, unemployment's still, like, sky-high, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But is that really realistic? I mean, unemployment's still, like, sky-high, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That damage has the potential to weigh on earnings and profits for months, if not years, and a soaring unemployment rate will only worsen the situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! There's major damage. The Fed even said most businesses are just *optimistic*, not necessarily thriving. Banks are predicting sharp declines through 2025.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! There's major damage. The Fed even said most businesses are just optimistic, not necessarily thriving. Banks are predicting sharp declines through twenty twenty five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So it's almost like the market is way ahead of itself, or, uh, maybe disconnected from reality?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's almost like the market is way ahead of itself, or, uh, maybe disconnected from reality?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's it. As one analyst put it, the market prices in recovery *well before* the economic data bottoms. It's always looking ahead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's it. As one analyst put it, the market prices in recovery well before the economic data bottoms. It's always looking ahead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, we're seeing this crazy S&P run, but it could, like, just dip into something much worse later on?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we're seeing this crazy S and P run, but it could, like, just dip into something much worse later on?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Potentially. The big unknown is, um, where exactly that peak is going to fall. We just don't know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potentially. The big unknown is, um, where exactly that peak is going to fall. We just don't know.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: WHAT WE DONT KNOW Where the bottom of the market will fall.
